InterSpec is a product of Sandia National Laboratories (SNL), with development supported by NNSA‘s Office of Nuclear Smuggling Detection and Deterrence (NSDD). Initial development of InterSpec was funded by the Science and Technology Directorate of the Department of Homeland Security
William Johnson is the primary developer of InterSpec, with Ethan Chan, David Ka-Ming Lee, and Christian Morte providing substantial contributions. Extensive additional support has been provided by Noel Nachtigal and Edward Walsh.

InterSpec uses a number of open-source libraries and publicly available resources, including:
Wt a C++ library for web development.
InterSpec uses Wt extensively to render the HTML based GUI, to facilitate user interactions, and for database object-relational mapping. Wt is available under either the GNU GPL Version 2 license, or a commercial license; commercial licenses were purchased for the SNL developers of InterSpec.
Boost C++ libraries.
InterSpec uses Boost for a host of tasks, including: as a dependancy to Wt, unit testing, mathematical constants and distributions, input parsing, working with date/times, linear algebra, hashing, supplements to the c++ language, and more. Boost is licensed under the Boost Software License.
RapidXml C++ XML Parser.
A slightly modified version of this library, which allows parsing of some non-compliant XML files, is used for all XML parsing tasks within InterSpec; all modifications are included and marked with the source code of InterSpec. RapidXml is licensed under the Boost Software License.
pugixml Light-weight, simple and fast XML parser for C++ with XPath support.
pugixml is used by the spectrum file query tool to parse an XPath query event XML files. pugixml is licensed under the MIT License. (Windows, Linux, macOS builds only)
Minuit2: Minimization Package.
Minuit2 is part Cern's ROOT package, and is used to perform numerical optizations for peak, energy calibration, and shielding/source-activity fitting. Minuit2 is licensed under the LGPL v2.1 License.
Cuba 3.0: a library for multidimensional numerical integration
Cuba is used to perform the numericall integration for self-attenuation sources in the shielding/source tool. Cuba is licensed under the LGPL v3 License.
muparserx 4.0.7: c++ Math Parser Library.
muparserx is used to evaluate user entered detector efficiencies, and to help evaluate expressions for the TerminalWidget (not all builds of InterSpec contain this tool). muparserx is licensed under the BSD License.
Electron: Package based on the Chromium web browser to build cross platform desktop apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS.
Electron is used to display app contents on standalone Windows and Linux versions of InterSpec. Electron is licensed under the MIT License, but libraries it uses may be licensed under other terms; see Electrons git repository for more information.
SQLite: SQL database engine.
SQLite is used to save user preferences and application state. SQLite is Public Domain software.
ROOT: A modular scientific software framework.
InterSpec uses code derived from the ROOT TSpectrum class to estimate the continuum for a spectrum (a depreciated feature); code used is marked and attributed within the InterSpec source code. ROOT is licensed under the LGPL v2.1 License.
jQuery 1.11.1: javascript library.
jQuery is used to help deal with cross-browser idiosyncrasies in the client-side java script. jQuery is licensed under the MIT License.
qTip2 2.2.0: javascript library that provides tooltip and notification tools.
qTip2 is used to help make the content-rich tooltips, as well as the notifications within InterSpec. qTip2 is licensed under the MIT License.
d3.js: a JavaScript charting library.
d3.js powers rendering and interactions of the spectrum chart, gross-count time chart, and decay tool. d3.js is licensed under the BSD License.
jQuery QueryBuilder: jQuery plugin for user friendly query/filter creator.
QueryBuilder is used to construct spectrum file queries. QueryBuilder is MIT licensed javascript library. (Windows, Linux, macOS builds only)
spectrum.js: The No Hassle jQuery Colorpicker.
spectrum.js is select colors throughout InterSpec when a native HTML5 is not used. spectrum.js is MIT licensed javascript library.
resize-observer-polyfill: A polyfill for the Resize Observer API.
resize-observer-polyfill is used to support the JavaScript ResizeObserver functionality for older browsers that do not natively support API. resize-observer-polyfill is MIT licensed javascript library.
zlib: A Massively Spiffy Yet Delicately Unobtrusive Compression Library.
zlib is used to open user uploaded zip files that contain spectrum files. zlib is ZLIB licensed library.
libHaru: free PDF library.
libHaru is used for the macOS build to help provide the Quick Look preview of spectrum files inside the Finder. libHaru is ZLIB licensed library.
QR Code generator library: Multiple programming language QR code generator.
QR Code generator library is used to generate QR codes throughout InterSpec; notably to represent detector response functions. QR Code generator library is MIT licensed library.
libpng: libpng is the official PNG reference library.
libpng is only on the macOS app build as part of rendering spectrum file previews in the Finder. libpng is PNG Reference Library License version 2 library.
Ceres Solver (version 2.1.0): Ceres Solver is an open source C++ library for modeling and solving large, complicated optimization problems.
Ceres Solver is used, for the the Relative Efficiency tools ("Isotopics by nuclides" and "Isotopics from peaks"); it may be used for peak-fitting as well in the future. Ceres Solver is BSD License library.
Eigen (version 3.4.0): Eigen is a C++ template library for linear algebra: matrices, vectors, numerical solvers, and related algorithms.
Eigen is used used by the Ceres Solver library, as well as a few places within the Relative Efficiency tools for some matrix operations. Eigen is Mozilla Public License Version 2.0 library.
wxWidgets (version 3.2.1): wxWidgets is a C++ library that lets developers create applications for Windows, macOS, Linux and other platforms with a single code base.
wxWidgets is used for displaying a WebView to render the application in, on some Windows and Linux builds. wxWidgets is wxWindows Library Licence, Version 3.1 library.
The Leaflet-based map feature uses a number of Javascript libraries to help display map data:
Leaflet: an open-source JavaScript library for mobile-friendly interactive maps. Leaflet is BSD 2-Clause "Simplified" License library.
Esri Leaflet: Leaflet plugins for working with a handful of the most popular ArcGIS Service types. Esri Leaflet is Apache License 2.0 library.
Esri Leaflet Vector Tile Plugin (version 4.0.0): A plugin for Esri Leaflet to visualize Vector tiles from ArcGIS Online. Esri Leaflet Vector Tile Plugin is Apache License 2.0 library.
Leaflet-Geoman (version 2.14.1): Leaflet Plugin For Creating And Editing Geometry Layers. Leaflet-Geoman is MIT licensed library.
d3-polygon (version 3.0.1): This module provides a few basic geometric operations for two-dimensional polygons. d3-polygon is ISC licensed library.
Leaflet.heat (version 0.2.0): A tiny, simple and fast Leaflet heatmap plugin. Leaflet.heat is BSD 2-Clause "Simplified" License library.
Leaflet.markercluster (version 1.5.3): Provides Beautiful Animated Marker Clustering functionality for Leaflet, a JS library for interactive maps. Leaflet.markercluster is MIT licensed library.
Leaflet.EasyButton (version 2.4.0): The easiest way to add buttons with Leaflet. Leaflet.EasyButton is MIT licensed library.
Leaflet.Measure (git hash 20e0e7d): A leaflet plugin for measuring distances and areas. Leaflet.Measure is MIT licensed library.
ZXing-C++ (git hash 9ca0684): ZXing-C++ ("zebra crossing") is an open-source, multi-format linear/matrix barcode image processing library implemented in C++.
ZXing-C++ is used to look for QR-codes in images that are opened in InterSpec. ZXing-C++ is Apache License 2.0 library.
In addition to the many libraries used within InterSpec, many open-source, or publicly available tools and resources are used to develop InterSpec including, but not limited to:
Evaluated Nuclear Structure Data File (ENSDF): used to derive nuclear decay information and gamma cross sections.
Geant4: Used to extract gamma cross section data from ENSDF to a custom format for InterSpec. Also used to validate physics calculations.
A number of build tools, including: CMake, GCC, Clang/LLVM, Microsoft Visual Studio, Python, git, and many more have been used to develop, compile, link, or otherwise produce InterSpec.
GadrasDRF: used to obtain detector response functions and create simulated data to test against.
